information_requirement: Has the adversary deployed acquired malware within the environment? (PIR)

evidence.description: A file observed traversing the network or written to an endpoint has a cryptographic hash (MD5, SHA1, SHA256) that matches a known malicious indicator from an integrated threat intelligence platform.
evidence.nai: Network egress points, Internal file servers, Web content filters, User endpoints
action: Symbolic: Join the SHA256 hash from file creation logs (Sysmon Event ID 11), process creation logs (Sysmon Event ID 1), or network file logs (Zeek file.log) against a watchlist of known malicious file hashes from threat intelligence feeds. Alert on any match.

Statistical: For all observed file hashes across the enterprise, calculate the prevalence (stack count) over a 24-hour window. Flag hashes seen on a very small number of endpoints (e.g., fewer than 5 or below the 1st percentile of prevalence) for further investigation as potentially unique malicious tools.

Machine Learning: Use a classification model (e.g., Random Forest or Gradient Boosting) trained on file metadata (MIME type, size, entropy, hash prevalence) and threat intelligence labels (benign/malicious) to predict the likelihood that a newly observed file is malicious. Alert on files with a high-confidence malicious score.

evidence.description: An endpoint initiates a network connection to an external IP address, domain, or URL that is present on a threat intelligence feed of known malware distribution points or Command and Control (C2) servers.
evidence.nai: Network egress points, DNS resolvers, Web proxies, User endpoints
action: Symbolic: Query DNS logs (Zeek dns.log) for requests to domains on a C2 watchlist. Query connection logs (Zeek conn.log, Sysmon Event ID 3) for connections to IP addresses on a malicious infrastructure watchlist. Query HTTP/SSL logs (Zeek http.log, Zeek ssl.log) for host headers or SNIs matching a malicious domain watchlist. Alert on any match.

Statistical: For all external domains queried (Zeek dns.log), calculate the age of the domain and its query prevalence across the organization. Flag domains that are newly registered (e.g., < 30 days old) and have a low query count (e.g., requested by < 0.1% of hosts), as this combination is common for malicious infrastructure.

Machine Learning: Develop a DGA (Domain Generation Algorithm) detection model using features like domain name length, character entropy, n-gram frequency, and the presence of numbers. Apply this model to all DNS queries in Zeek dns.log to score and identify algorithmically generated domains commonly used by malware for C2.

Symbolic: Query DNS logs (Zeek dns.log) for requests to domains on a C2 watchlist. Query connection logs (Zeek conn.log, Sysmon Event ID 3) for connections to IP addresses on a malicious infrastructure watchlist. Query HTTP/SSL logs (Zeek http.log, Zeek ssl.log) for host headers or SNIs matching a malicious domain watchlist. Alert on any match.

evidence.description: A process is created with a command line or parent-child process relationship that matches a known pattern for malware execution or a commodity offensive tool.
evidence.nai: Critical servers (e.g., Domain Controllers, database servers), User endpoints, Virtual Desktop Infrastructure (VDI) fleet
action: Symbolic: Apply Sigma or YARA-L rules against process creation logs (Windows Event ID 4688, Sysmon Event ID 1) to detect exact command-line matches for known malware droppers or post-exploitation tools (e.g., specific Cobalt Strike, Mimikatz, or PowerShell Empire argument patterns).

Statistical: For each parent process (e.g., `winword.exe`, `powershell.exe`), build a baseline of normal child processes and calculate the frequency of each relationship. Alert when a statistically rare child process is spawned (e.g., `powershell.exe` from `winword.exe` if this is below the 5th percentile of observed child processes for Word).

Machine Learning: Use a sequence-based anomaly detection model (e.g., LSTM Autoencoder) on tokenized command-line arguments. Train the model on legitimate command lines for common processes (`powershell.exe`, `cmd.exe`, `wscript.exe`). Flag new command lines that have a high reconstruction error, indicating they are anomalous and potentially malicious.

evidence.description: A newly created process, characterized by an anomalous file path, a name masquerading as a system binary, or a lack of a valid digital signature, initiates an outbound network connection to a destination not previously contacted by that host.
evidence.nai: User endpoints, Public-facing web servers, Network egress points
action: Symbolic: Search Sysmon Event 3 logs for network connections originating from processes that are unsigned (`Signed: false`) or are masquerading as system binaries (e.g., `Image` is `C:\\Users\\Public\\svchost.exe`). Alert if the destination is external and not on an allowlist.

Statistical: For each process name, calculate the Shannon entropy of its file path. Establish a baseline entropy score for legitimate system processes. Alert when a process is executed from a path with an entropy score exceeding 3 standard deviations from its baseline mean (e.g., `C:\\Windows\\Temp\\asdfwernxcv.exe`).

Machine Learning: Train a clustering model (e.g., DBSCAN) on a feature set of correlated process and network events: {process path entropy, is_signed, parent_process_name, destination_IP_prevalence, destination_port}. Identify small clusters of activity that deviate from the large, dense clusters representing normal system and user behavior.

evidence.description: An internal host's network traffic exhibits one or more anomalous characteristics indicative of C2 communication: 1) periodic, fixed-interval connections (beaconing), 2) use of non-standard ports for common protocols, or 3) connections to low-prevalence or geographically anomalous destinations.
evidence.nai: Network egress points, VPN concentrators, Server subnets
action: Symbolic: Search Zeek conn.log for connections where the `service` field is `ssl` but the `id.resp_p` (destination port) is not 443. Correlate with Zeek ssl.log to check for self-signed certificates (`validation_status` contains 'self-signed'). Alert on a confirmed match.

Statistical: For each source-destination IP pair in Zeek conn.log, calculate the time delta between consecutive connections over a 24-hour period. A very low standard deviation of these time deltas (e.g., < 1 second) combined with a low mean time delta (e.g., 60 seconds) indicates highly regular, machine-generated beaconing. Alert on pairs with a low standard deviation and a connection count > 10.

Machine Learning: Apply time-series decomposition (e.g., Seasonal-Trend-Loess) to a host's outbound data volume binned in 1-minute intervals. A strong, repeating seasonal component with a short period (e.g., 5 minutes) that is not synchronized with business hours can indicate automated C2 beaconing activity.

evidence.description: A file object is observed with multiple characteristics associated with evasion: 1) a filename with high character entropy, 2) a double extension (e.g., 'report.pdf.exe'), and 3) a mismatch between its file extension and its true file type identified by MIME type or magic number.
evidence.nai: Email gateways, Web proxies, Internal file servers, User endpoints
action: Symbolic: Using a regular expression, search the `filename` field in Zeek file.log or `TargetFilename` in Sysmon Event ID 11 for patterns like `\\.[a-z]{3,4}\\.exe$`. Also, create a rule to alert where `mime_type` in Zeek file.log is 'application/x-dosexec' but the filename extension is not `.exe`, `.dll`, or `.scr`.

Statistical: Calculate the Shannon entropy for all filenames observed in Zeek file.log and Sysmon Event ID 11. Establish a baseline distribution of entropy scores for the environment. Alert on any filename with an entropy score in the top 1% (e.g., > 4.5), which often indicates randomized names used by malware.

Machine Learning: Use an unsupervised anomaly detection model (e.g., Isolation Forest) on file features from Zeek file.log: {filename entropy, file size, MIME type, source/destination pair prevalence}. The model will learn normal file transfer patterns and score events that are 'easy to isolate' as anomalous and worthy of investigation.
